egypt_symbol_notes.bow: Warfare and hunting tool; often a phonogram (q/p/k depending on context) and a determinative for martial power, subjugation, or protection.
egypt_symbol_notes.hoe: Agricultural implement tied to cultivation and ritual ‚Äòpreparation‚Äô; used as a determinative and phonetic sign.
egypt_symbol_notes.god_figure: Anthropomorphic marker indicating divine agency; commonly a determinative for deities.
egypt_symbol_notes.bread: Offering loaf symbolizing food and sustenance; phonetic value 't'.
egypt_symbol_notes.feather: Represents the concepts of truth and balance; phonetic value 'm'.
egypt_symbol_notes.eye: Wedjat eye symbolizing protection and healing; phonetic for 'ir' or 'jr'.
egypt_symbol_notes.owl: Common phonogram 'm'; also signifies night and hidden knowledge.
egypt_symbol_notes.reed: Symbol for writing and speech; phonetic and determinative use.
egypt_symbol_notes.leg: Indicates motion, going forth, phonetic sign.
egypt_symbol_notes.lizard: Represents reptiles; associated with protective symbolism.
egypt_symbol_notes.woman_seated: Determinative for female persons or roles.
egypt_symbol_notes.jar: Associated with offerings, fluids, and ritual context.
egypt_symbol_notes.crown: Symbol of royal authority and divine power.
egypt_symbol_notes.man_seated: Determinative for male persons or generic agents.

greek_symbol_notes.Œö: Kappa: Tenth letter, consonant /k/ sound, equivalent to Latin C/K.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ≥: Lowercase gamma, consonant /g/ sound, or nasal /ng/ before Œ≥, Œ∫, œá, Œæ sounds.
greek_symbol_notes.Œπ: Lowercase iota, vowel /i/ sound, can form diphthongs with other vowels.
greek_symbol_notes.Œù: Nu: Thirteenth letter, consonant /n/ sound, nasal consonant with grammatical functions.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ§: Tau: Nineteenth letter, consonant /t/ sound, common in grammatical endings.
greek_symbol_notes.Œø: Lowercase omicron, short vowel /o/ sound, frequent in grammatical morphemes.
greek_symbol_notes.Œª: Lowercase lambda, consonant /l/ sound, liquid consonant with metrical significance.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ∏: Lowercase theta, aspirated /t ∞/ sound, distinguishes words from similar tau forms.
greek_symbol_notes.œÖ: Lowercase upsilon, vowel /y/ sound, forms diphthongs and appears in many endings.
greek_symbol_notes.Œò: Theta: Eighth letter, aspirated /t ∞/ sound in ancient Greek, /Œ∏/ (voiceless th) in modern.
greek_symbol_notes.Œó: Eta: Seventh letter, long vowel /ƒì/ sound in ancient Greek, /i/ in modern Greek.
greek_symbol_notes.œÇ: Lowercase sigma (final form), consonant /s/ sound, used only at word endings.
greek_symbol_notes.Œµ: Lowercase epsilon, short vowel /e/ sound, appears frequently in verb conjugations.
greek_symbol_notes.-: Hyphen; marks word division or compound elements in Greek texts.
greek_symbol_notes.·øö: Capital Iota with grave accent, indicates lowered pitch or unstressed position.
greek_symbol_notes.·øñ: Lowercase iota with circumflex accent, indicates falling tone on long vowel /ƒ´/.
greek_symbol_notes.ŒØ: Lowercase iota with acute accent, vowel /i/ with raised pitch indicating word stress.
greek_symbol_notes.·º∏: Capital Iota with smooth breathing, vowel /i/ without initial aspiration.
greek_symbol_notes.·ºô: Capital Epsilon with rough breathing, indicates /h/ sound before vowel.
greek_symbol_notes.': Apostrophe; indicates elision (omitted vowel) or contraction in Greek.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ†: Pi: Sixteenth letter, consonant /p/ sound, appears in mathematical and scientific contexts.
greek_symbol_notes.Œü: Omicron: Fifteenth letter, short vowel /o/ sound, distinct from omega (long o).
greek_symbol_notes.Œú: Mu: Twelfth letter, consonant /m/ sound, nasal consonant often used in word formation.
greek_symbol_notes.[: Opening square bracket; typically editorial reconstructions or uncertain readings.
greek_symbol_notes.Œë: Alpha: First letter of Greek alphabet, vowel /a/ sound, often marks beginnings or primacy.
greek_symbol_notes.Œº: Lowercase mu, consonant /m/ sound, nasal consonant often in prefixes and roots.
greek_symbol_notes.·Ω≤: Lowercase epsilon with grave accent, short /e/ sound with lowered pitch.
greek_symbol_notes.·æπ: Capital Alpha with macron (long mark), indicates long /ƒÅ/ vowel quantity.
greek_symbol_notes.Œì: Gamma: Third letter, consonant /g/ sound, or /ng/ before Œ≥, Œ∫, œá, Œæ sounds.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ•: Upsilon: Twentieth letter, vowel /y/ sound in ancient Greek, /i/ in modern pronunciation.
greek_symbol_notes.(: Opening parenthesis; editorial or explanatory insertions.
greek_symbol_notes.): Closing parenthesis; completes editorial or explanatory insertions.
greek_symbol_notes.œâ: Lowercase omega, long vowel /≈ç/ sound, often in verb endings and declensions.
greek_symbol_notes.·øë: Lowercase iota with macron, explicitly marks long vowel quantity /ƒ´/.
greek_symbol_notes.¬∑: Middle dot (Greek semicolon); equivalent to modern semicolon, marks major pause.
greek_symbol_notes.·øê: Lowercase iota with breve, explicitly marks short vowel quantity /ƒ≠/.
greek_symbol_notes.Œû: Xi: Fourteenth letter, consonant cluster /ks/ sound, compound sound written as single letter.
greek_symbol_notes.ŒΩ: Lowercase nu, consonant /n/ sound, assimilates before consonants in pronunciation.
greek_symbol_notes.Œï: Epsilon: Fifth letter, short vowel /e/ sound, distinct from eta (long e).
greek_symbol_notes.Œ∑: Lowercase eta, long vowel /ƒì/ sound in ancient Greek, /i/ in modern pronunciation.
greek_symbol_notes.]: Closing square bracket; completes editorial reconstructions.
greek_symbol_notes.Œô: Iota: Ninth letter, vowel /i/ sound, can form diphthongs with other vowels.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ∫: Lowercase kappa, consonant /k/ sound, common in word formation and inflection.
greek_symbol_notes.1: Numeral one; manuscript numbering, line numbers, or verse citations.
greek_symbol_notes.·øÉ: Lowercase eta with iota subscript, indicates original diphthong /ƒìi/ sound.
greek_symbol_notes.œà: Lowercase psi, consonant cluster /ps/ sound, compound phoneme as single letter.
greek_symbol_notes.·º¢: Lowercase eta with rough breathing and grave accent, aspirated long vowel with lowered tone.
greek_symbol_notes.·Ωü: Capital Upsilon with rough breathing and circumflex, indicates aspiration and falling tone.
greek_symbol_notes.·ºπ: Capital Iota with rough breathing, vowel /i/ with initial aspiration /h/.
greek_symbol_notes.·æ∏: Capital Alpha with breve (short mark), indicates short /ƒÉ/ vowel quantity.
greek_symbol_notes.Œä: Capital Iota with acute accent, indicates raised pitch or primary word stress.
greek_symbol_notes.Œõ: Lambda: Eleventh letter, consonant /l/ sound, liquid consonant in Greek phonology.
greek_symbol_notes.\": Quotation mark; marks direct speech or citations in Greek texts.
greek_symbol_notes.œÉ: Lowercase sigma (medial form), consonant /s/ sound, used within words.
greek_symbol_notes.·º©: Capital Eta with rough breathing, long /ƒì/ sound with initial aspiration /h/.
greek_symbol_notes.Œß: Chi: Twenty-second letter, aspirated /k ∞/ sound in ancient Greek, /x/ (voiceless velar fricative) in modern.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ∂: Lowercase zeta, consonant cluster /zd/ sound, represents compound phoneme.
greek_symbol_notes.·ºø: Capital Iota with rough breathing and circumflex accent, complex tonal marking.
greek_symbol_notes.·Ω∂: Lowercase iota with grave accent, vowel /i/ with lowered pitch or unstressed.
greek_symbol_notes.·º∞: Lowercase iota with smooth breathing, vowel /i/ without initial aspiration.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ±: Lowercase alpha, vowel /a/ sound, fundamental vowel in Greek phonology.
greek_symbol_notes.,: Comma; punctuation for pauses, lists, or grammatical separation.
greek_symbol_notes.·æó: Lowercase eta with rough breathing, circumflex accent, and iota subscript, complex phonetic marking.
greek_symbol_notes.œÑ: Lowercase tau, consonant /t/ sound, appears in many grammatical suffixes.
greek_symbol_notes.<: Less-than symbol; editorial mark for textual corrections or variants.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ£: Sigma: Eighteenth letter, consonant /s/ sound, has special final form (œÇ) at word end.
greek_symbol_notes.œÅ: Lowercase rho, consonant /r/ sound, when word-initial requires rough breathing mark.
greek_symbol_notes.·º°: Lowercase eta with rough breathing, long /ƒì/ sound with initial /h/.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ©: Omega: Twenty-fourth letter, long vowel /≈ç/ sound in ancient Greek, /o/ in modern.
Period (full stop); marks end of sentences in Greek texts.
greek_symbol_notes.·ø¨: Capital Rho with rough breathing, indicates /hr/ sound at word beginning (all word-initial rhos are aspirated).
greek_symbol_notes.·ºï: Lowercase epsilon with rough breathing and acute accent, aspirated short vowel with raised tone.
greek_symbol_notes.·øÜ: Lowercase eta with circumflex accent, falling tone on long vowel /ƒì/.
greek_symbol_notes.·ºæ: Capital Iota with smooth breathing and circumflex accent, vowel /ƒ´/ with falling tone, no initial aspiration.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ≤: Lowercase beta, consonant /b/ sound in ancient Greek, /v/ sound in modern Greek pronunciation.
greek_symbol_notes.·Ωâ: Capital Omicron with rough breathing, short /o/ sound with initial aspiration /h/.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ™: Capital Iota with diaeresis (trema), indicates /i/ vowel pronounced separately, not as diphthong.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ¶: Phi: Twenty-first letter, aspirated /p ∞/ sound in ancient Greek, /f/ in modern pronunciation.
greek_symbol_notes.·øó: Lowercase iota with diaeresis and circumflex, /ƒ´/ vowel with falling tone, pronounced separately.
greek_symbol_notes.Œ≠: Lowercase epsilon with acute accent (modern Greek), short /e/ sound with stress marking.
greek_symbol_notes.·º∑: Lowercase iota with rough breathing and circumflex accent, aspirated /ƒ´/ vowel with falling tone.

latin_symbol_notes.Íú†: Modifier letter for stress and high tone, used in phonetic transcription and transliteration.
latin_symbol_notes.Íú°: Modifier letter for stress and low tone, common in linguistic notation.
latin_symbol_notes.Íú¢: Capital Letter Egyptological Alef, used in transliterating Egyptian hieroglyphs.
latin_symbol_notes.Íú£: Small Letter Egyptological Alef, counterpart to capital version.
latin_symbol_notes.Íú§: Capital Letter Egyptological Ain, reflecting voiced pharyngeal sounds in transliteration.
latin_symbol_notes.Íú•: Small Letter Egyptological Ain, used in Semitic transliterations.
latin_symbol_notes.ÍùÄ: Capital Letter K with Stroke, scribal abbreviation mark for legal or medieval texts.
latin_symbol_notes.ÍùÅ: Small Letter K with Stroke, similar abbreviation symbol.
latin_symbol_notes.Íùë: Small Letter P with Stroke Through Descender, abbreviation of 'per' in medieval Latin manuscripts.
latin_symbol_notes.Íùõ: Small Letter R Rotunda, a stylistic medieval form of 'r' to save space.
latin_symbol_notes.ÍûÄ: Capital Letter Turned L, used in paleography to denote variant forms.
latin_symbol_notes.ÍûÅ: Small Letter Turned L, lowercase variant in medieval scripts.
latin_symbol_notes.ÍûÇ: Capital Letter Insular R, found in Insular script manuscripts in medieval Britain and Ireland.
latin_symbol_notes.Íùª: Capital Letter Insular F, distinct letter in Celtic Insular manuscripts.
latin_symbol_notes.ÍüΩ: Epigraphic Letter Inverted M, used as a logogram for 'mulier' or 'matrona' in Roman inscriptions.
latin_symbol_notes.Íüø: Epigraphic Letter Archaic M, represents the praenomen 'Manius' in inscriptions.

cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÄÄ: Cuneiform sign A: vowel sound /a/ in Sumerian and Akkadian, fundamental vowel marker
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÄ≠: Cuneiform sign AN/DINGIR: divine determinative, heaven, god concept in religious texts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íàó: Cuneiform sign LUGAL: king, ruler, sovereign used in royal inscriptions and titles
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íäï: Cuneiform sign UD: day, sun, light, time marker in calendrical and chronological contexts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÑø: Cuneiform sign I: vowel /i/, often used in verbal forms and grammatical particles
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÇç: Cuneiform sign E: house, temple, building in architectural and religious contexts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÄ∏: Cuneiform sign ARAD: servant, slave, worker in administrative and legal documents
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÅπ: Cuneiform sign DIRIG: to exceed, surplus, extra in mathematical and accounting texts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íâã: Cuneiform sign TI: life, to live, arrow in medical, military, and philosophical contexts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÜ†: Cuneiform sign KI: earth, place, land in geographical and territorial designations
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íåì: Cuneiform sign ZU: to know, knowledge, wisdom in educational and scribal contexts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íà®: Cuneiform sign ME: divine powers, cultural practices in mythological and religious texts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íâø: Cuneiform sign TUKU: to have, possess, hold in commercial and legal transactions
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÑ©: Cuneiform sign HA: fish, to catch in texts about fishing, food, and economy
cuneiform_symbol_notes.íÅá: Cuneiform sign DU: to go, walk, build in construction, travel, and action contexts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.lugal: ATF: lugal - Sumerian/Akkadian for 'king', royal title in administrative texts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.an: ATF: an - Sky god An/Anu, heaven concept in religious and mythological contexts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.ki: ATF: ki - Earth, place, land in geographical and cosmological descriptions
cuneiform_symbol_notes.dingir: ATF: dingir - God, divine being, deity in religious and ceremonial texts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.sar: ATF: sar - To write, inscription, totality in scribal and administrative contexts
cuneiform_symbol_notes.{d}: ATF: determinative for divine names, indicates following word refers to a deity

cuneiform_hint: Cuneiform signs represent syllables, words, or concepts in ancient Mesopotamian languages (Sumerian, Akkadian, Hittite, etc.). ATF format uses Latin transliteration of cuneiform symbols.
greek_hint: If no specific character note is found, treat as lexical marker considering diacriticals (breathing marks, accents, vowel quantity) which affect pronunciation, meaning, and grammatical function in ancient Greek texts.
latin_hint: Letters and symbols reflect phonetic values and scribal practices in manuscripts.
